sen.j: 飯豊青皇女（いいとよあおのひめみこ、允恭天皇29年（440年）? - 清寧天皇5年（484年）11月 (旧暦)?）は、記紀に伝えられる5世紀末の皇族（王族）。
sen.e: Iitoyo no himemiko (Emperor Ingyo 29, 440? - Emperor Seinei 5, November 484) was one of Imperial families (the royal family) during the end of fifth century, according to "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan."
Iitoyo no himemiko (440? - 484) was one of Imperial family (the royal family) during the end of fifth century, according to "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan."
sen.cmt: 規定により、旧暦の月日を削除しました。
sen.e: Iitoyo no himemiko (440? - 484) was one of Imperial family (the royal family) during the end of fifth century, according to "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan."

sen.j: 履中天皇の皇女、または市辺押磐皇子の王女で、第22代清寧天皇の崩御後に一時政を執ったとされる。
sen.e: She was an Imperial princess of Emperor Richu or a princess of Prince Ichinobe no Oshihano and after the death of the twenty-second Emperor Seinei she is said to have addressed affairs of state temporarily.

She was an Imperial princess of Emperor Richu or a princess of Prince Ichinobe no Oshihano and after the death of the twenty-second Emperor Seinei she is said to have addressed affairs of state temporarily.

She was an Imperial princess of Emperor Richu or a princess of Prince Ichinobe no Oshihano and after the death of the twenty-second Emperor Seinei she is said to have addressed affairs of state temporarily.

sen.j: 飯豊皇女または飯豊王女と書かれることも多い。
sen.e: 飯豊青皇女 is often written as 飯豊皇女 or 飯豊王女.
飯豊青皇女 is often written as 飯豊皇女 or 飯豊王女.
飯豊青皇女 is often written as 飯豊皇女 or 飯豊王女.

sen.j: 飯豊女王、飯豊王、飯豊郎女、青海皇女、青海郎女、忍海郎女、忍海部女王とも。
sen.e: Also written as 飯豊女王, 飯豊王, 飯豊郎女, 青海皇女, 青海郎女, 忍海郎女 and 忍海部女王.

sen.j: 「いひとよ」とは古語でフクロウのことをいい、古代ギリシアでは知恵の象徴であった。
sen.e: Iitoyo' is an owl in ancient words and was the symbol of Chie (wisdom, knowledge) in ancient Greek.
Iitoyo' is an owl in ancient words and was the symbol of Chie (wisdom, knowledge) in ancient Greek.
Iitoyo' is an owl in ancient words and was the symbol of Chie (wisdom, knowledge) in ancient Greek.

sen.j: 「おしぬみ」は葛城内の地名・忍海郡で、飯豊王の本拠地。
sen.e: Oshinumi' is a place name Oshimi-gun in Katsuragi and the home ground for Iitoyo.
Oshinumi' is a place name Oshimi-gun in Katsuragi and the home ground for Iitoyo.
Oshinumi' is a place name Oshimi-gun in Katsuragi and the home ground for Iitoyo.

sen.j: 忍海部は、飯豊王の名代（こしろ）の部民制（べのたみ）であるが、単なる農民部ではなく東漢氏（あやひと）をかかえた雑工部（物品製造に携わる職工集団）でもあったらしい。
sen.e: Oshinumibe was bemin sei (the system of Yamato Dynasty) of Iitoyo's representative, but it seems to have been not just a department of peasants, but a department of manufacturers (mechanic company to produce items) including Ayahito clan.

Oshinumibe was bemin sei (the system of Yamato Dynasty) of Iitoyo's representative, but it seems to have been not just a department of peasants, but a department of manufacturers (mechanic company to produce items) including Ayahito clan.

sen.j: 「あをみ」は不詳（あるいは青海郎女の「青海」や飯豊青尊の「青」は福井県大飯郡高浜町内の地名かとも思われる）。
sen.e: Aomi' is unknown (or 'aomi' of Aomi no iratsume or 'ao' of 'Iitoyo ao no mikoto' seem to be place names in Takahama-cho, Oi-gun, Fukui Prefecture).

sen.cmt: スペース削除しました。
sen.e: Aomi' is unknown (or 'aomi' of Aomi no iratsume or 'ao' of 'Iitoyo ao no mikoto' seem to be place names in Takahama-cho, Oi-gun, Fukui Prefecture).

sen.j: 修二会の過去帳拝読で読まれる「青衣の女人（しょうえのにょにん）」や、葛城山の枕詞（木幡、忍坂山等にも掛かる）の「青旗」等、「青」の意味を考える価値はあると考えられる。
sen.e: Shoe no nyonin' (a women in blue cloth) in the reading of a family register of deaths in Shuni-e (Omizu-tori or Sacred Water-drawing Festival) or 'blue flag' in the makurakotoba (a set epithet) of Mt. Katsuragi and so on, the meaning of 'blue' is worth of considering.

sen.j: 第22代清寧天皇と第23代顕宗天皇との間の期間、執政者だったと伝えられ、女性天皇の先駆的存在として注目される（時代的には、神功皇后と推古天皇をつなぐ位置にある）。
sen.e: During the period between the twenty-second Emperor Seinei and the twenty-third Emperor Kenzo, she is said to have been an administrator and attracts attention as a pioneer of Empress (periodically, she was positioned between Empress Jingu and Empress Suiko).

During the period between the twenty-second Emperor Seinei and the twenty-third Emperor Kenzo, she is said to have been an administrator and attracts attention as a pioneer of Empress (periodically, she was positioned between Empress Jingu and Empress Suiko).

During the period between the twenty-second Emperor Seinei and the twenty-third Emperor Kenzo, she is said to have been an administrator and attracts attention as a pioneer of Empress (periodically, she was positioned between Empress Jingu and Empress Suiko).

sen.j: 『日本書紀』によると、男性と経験を持ったのは生涯1度だけであったという（格別に記紀には何も書かれてないがもしかしたら男勝りな性格だったのかも知れない）。
sen.e: According to "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), she is said to have experienced only one sex with a man in her life (Especially in "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan" nothing is written, but maybe she had a masculine character).

sen.j: 葛城埴口丘陵（かずらきのはにくちのおかのみささぎ、『延喜式』諸陵寮には埴口墓）に葬られた。
sen.e: She was buried in Kazuraki no hanikuchi no oka no misasagi, hanikuchi grave in Shoryoryo (the Bureau for managing imperial mausoleums) in "the Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers).

She was buried in Kazuraki no hanikuchi no oka no misasagi, hanikuchi grave in Shoryoryo (the Bureau for managing imperial mausoleums) in "the Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers).

sen.j: 同陵は奈良県葛城市北花内の北花内大塚古墳（前方後円墳・全長90m）に比定される。
sen.e: The mausoleum is estimated as Kitahanauchi Otsuka kofun (tumulus) (large keyhole-shaped tomb mound, the entire length 90 meters) in Kitahanauchi, Katsuragi City, Nara Prefecture.
The mausoleum is estimated as Kitahanauchi Otsuka kofun (tumulus) (large keyhole-shaped tomb mound, the entire length 90 meters) in Kitahanauchi, Katsuragi City, Nara Prefecture.
The mausoleum is estimated as Kitahanauchi Otsuka kofun (tumulus) (large keyhole-shaped tomb mound, the entire length 90 meters) in Kitahanauchi, Katsuragi City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: ただし『日本書紀』は「陵」と表記し、天皇扱いし、「墓」ではないことは注目される。
sen.e: However in "Nihonshoki," it was described as '陵' not as '墓, ' which means that she was regarded as Emperor, which is worth of noticing.
However in "Nihonshoki," it was described as '陵' not as '墓, ' which means that she was regarded as Emperor, which is worth of noticing.
sen.cmt: スペース削除しました。
sen.e: However in "Nihonshoki," it was described as '陵' not as '墓, ' which means that she was regarded as Emperor, which is worth of noticing.

tit.cmt: ピリオド削除しました。

sen.j: 『日本書紀』によれば、執政期間は短くわずか10箇月余りで、清寧天皇5年（484年）11月に死死の表現（実際は「崩御」と表記し、天皇扱いにしている）。
sen.e: Acceding to "Nihonshoki," the duration of administration was only about ten months and she passed away in November in Emperor Seinei 5 (484) (in fact, she was treated as Emperor, describing it as 'hogyo (demise).'
sen.cmt: 「死死の表現」とは意味不明で、単に「逝去」の意味にとりました。
sen.e: Acceding to "Nihonshoki," the duration of administration was only about ten months and she passed away in November in Emperor Seinei 5 (484) (in fact, she was treated as Emperor, describing it as 'hogyo' [demise].)

Acceding to "Nihonshoki," the duration of administration was only about ten months and she passed away in November in Emperor Seinei 5 (484) (in fact, she was treated as Emperor, describing it as 'hogyo' [demise].)

sen.j: ただし、前後の清寧・顕宗天皇などの実在を否定する立場からは、執政期間がさらに数年に及ぶとの推定もある。
sen.e: However, some estimates that her administration was longer than a few years from the standpoint of denying the existence of the predecessor and successor Emperor Seinei and Emperor Kenzo.
However, some estimates that her administration was longer than a few years from the standpoint of denying the existence of the predecessor and successor Emperor Seinei and Emperor Kenzo.
However, some estimates that her administration was longer than a few years from the standpoint of denying the existence of the predecessor and successor Emperor Seinei and Emperor Kenzo.

sen.j: なお、年齢については、『水鏡』に「御年四十五（45歳）」とあり、これに基づいて逆算すれば、允恭天皇29年（440年）の誕生となるが、どれだけ史実を反映しているかは不明である。
sen.e: And as for her age, 'she is forty-five (45 years old),' was written in "Mizu Kagami (The Water Mirror)," and to calculate her age inversely based on this, it is Emperor Ingyo 29 (440), but it is not clear how it true to the historical fact.

And as for her age, 'she is forty-five (45 years old),' was written in "Mizu Kagami (The Water Mirror)," and to calculate her age inversely based on this, it is Emperor Ingyo 29 (440), but it is not clear how it true to the historical fact.

And as for her age, 'she is forty-five (45 years old),' was written in "Mizu Kagami (The Water Mirror)," and to calculate her age inversely based on this, it is Emperor Ingyo 29 (440), but it is not clear how it true to the historical fact.

tit.cmt: ピリオド削除しました。

sen.j: 女帝であったかなかったか。
sen.e: Was she an Empress or not?
Was she an Empress or not?
Was she an Empress or not?

sen.j: 記紀では天皇として認められていないが、後世の史書である『扶桑略記』に「飯豊天皇廿四代女帝」、『本朝皇胤紹運録』に「飯豊天皇 忍海部女王是也」と記される上、偽書の『先代旧事本紀大成経』には「清貞天皇（せいていてんのう）」の諡号まであり、天皇の扱いとなっている。
sen.e: In "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan" she was not regarded as Emperor, but in "Fuso Ryakki" (A Brief History of Japan) she was described as 'Emperor Iitoyo the fourth Empress,' in Honcho koin jounroku (the Emperor's family tree, made in the Muromachi period) as 'Iitoyo Emperor Oshinumibe princess,' and additionally in the apocryphal book 'Sendai Kujihongi taiseikyo,' there was even shigo (posthumous title) 'Emperor Seitei,' where she was treated as Emperor.

In "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan" she was not regarded as Emperor, but in "Fuso Ryakki" (A Brief History of Japan) she was described as 'Emperor Iitoyo the fourth Empress,' in Honcho koin jounroku (the Emperor's family tree, made in the Muromachi period) as 'Iitoyo Emperor Oshinumibe princess,' and additionally in the apocryphal book "Sendai Kujihongi taiseikyo," there was even shigo (posthumous title) 'Emperor Seitei,' where she was treated as Emperor.
sen.cmt: 『先代旧事本紀大成経』のシングルクオート→ダブルクオート、全角スペース→半角スペースしました。
sen.e: In "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan" she was not regarded as Emperor, but in "Fuso Ryakki" (A Brief History of Japan) she was described as 'Emperor Iitoyo the fourth Empress,' in Honcho koin jounroku (the Emperor's family tree, made in the Muromachi period) as 'Iitoyo Emperor Oshinumibe princess,' and additionally in the apocryphal book "Sendai Kujihongi taiseikyo," there was even shigo (posthumous title) 'Emperor Seitei,' where she was treated as Emperor.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション調整

sen.j: 一説には皇統譜でも天皇とされているというが未確認（また別の一説には、前述の生涯1度だけの性交渉ゆえに歴代から外されたのだともいう）。
sen.e: In one theory she was regarded as Emperor in Kotofu (the genealogy of the Imperial Family), but it is not confirmed (and in another theory, she was deleted from the history because she had only one intercourse in her life as mentioned above.

In one theory she was regarded as Emperor in Kotofu (the genealogy of the Imperial Family), but it is not confirmed (and in another theory, she was deleted from the history because she had only one intercourse in her life as mentioned above.

sen.j: 明治時代から昭和20年まで、いわゆる戦前には「歴代天皇の代数には含めないが、天皇の尊号を贈り奉る」としていた。
sen.e: From Meiji period to 1945, so-called in prewar times, 'she was not included in successive emperors, but was given the honorary title of Emperor.'
From Meiji period to 1945, so-called in prewar times, 'she was not included in successive emperors, but was given the honorary title of Emperor.'
From Meiji period to 1945, so-called in prewar times, 'she was not included in successive emperors, but was given the honorary title of Emperor.'

sen.j: 清寧天皇の代理（摂政？）だったのか、仁賢・顕宗両天皇の代理（摂政？）だったのか。
sen.e: Was she a representative (Sessho, regent) of Emperor Seinei or was she a representative (Sessho, regent) of both Emperor Ninken and Emperor Kenzo?
Was she a representative (Sessho, regent) of Emperor Seinei or was she a representative (Sessho, regent) of both Emperor Ninken and Emperor Kenzo?
Was she a representative (Sessho, regent) of Emperor Seinei or was she a representative (Sessho, regent) of both Emperor Ninken and Emperor Kenzo?

sen.j: 『日本書紀』によれば、清寧天皇の治世中にすでに仁賢天皇（おけのみこと）と顕宗天皇（おけのみこと）は発見されており、後継問題は解決されていたが、清寧天皇崩御後に億計尊と弘計尊が皇位を相譲したため、飯豊青皇女が忍海角刺宮（おしぬみのつのさしのみや、奈良県葛城市忍海郡の角刺神社が伝承地）で執政し、「忍海飯豊青尊」と称したという。
sen.e: According to "Nihonshoki," Emperor Ninken and Emperor Kenzo had already been discovered in the administration of Emperor Seinei and the successor issue was solved, but after the demise of Emperor Seinei, Oke no mikoto (億計尊) and Oke no mikoto (弘計尊) ceded the Imperial Throne and Iitoyo no himemiko engaged in state affairs in Oshinumi no tsunosashi no miya (Tsunosashi shrine in Oshimi-gun, Katsuragi City, Nara Prefecture is the traditional place) and called herself 'Oshimi Iitoyo ao no mikoto.'

According to "Nihonshoki," Emperor Ninken and Emperor Kenzo had already been discovered in the administration of Emperor Seinei and the successor issue was solved, but after the demise of Emperor Seinei, Oke no mikoto (億計尊) and Oke no mikoto (弘計尊) ceded the Imperial Throne and Iitoyo no himemiko engaged in state affairs in Oshinumi no tsunosashi no miya (Tsunosashi Shrine in Oshimi-gun, Katsuragi City, Nara Prefecture is the traditional place) and called herself 'Oshimi Iitoyo ao no mikoto.'

According to "Nihonshoki," Emperor Ninken and Emperor Kenzo had already been discovered in the administration of Emperor Seinei and the successor issue was solved, but after the demise of Emperor Seinei, Oke no mikoto (億計尊) and Oke no mikoto (弘計尊) ceded the Imperial Throne and Iitoyo no himemiko engaged in state affairs in Oshinumi no tsunosashi no miya (Tsunosashi Shrine in Oshimi-gun, Katsuragi City, Nara Prefecture is the traditional place) and called herself 'Oshimi Iitoyo ao no mikoto.'

sen.j: ところが『古事記』によれば、清寧天皇崩後に皇嗣なく、飯豊王が執政していたが、やがて（つまりその執政期間中に）億計・弘計の兄弟が発見され、兄弟を播磨国から迎えたとある。
sen.e: However in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), after the demise of Emperor Seinei, there was no Crown Prince and thus Iitoyo no himemiko addressed affairs of state, but later (that is, during her administration period) Oke no mikoto's brothers were found and she welcomed the brothers from Harima Province.

However in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), after the demise of Emperor Seinei, there was no Crown Prince and thus Iitoyo no himemiko addressed affairs of state, but later (that is, during her administration period) Oke no mikoto's brothers were found and she welcomed the brothers from Harima Province.

However in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), after the demise of Emperor Seinei, there was no Crown Prince and thus Iitoyo no himemiko addressed affairs of state, but later (that is, during her administration period) Oke no mikoto's brothers were found and she welcomed the brothers from Harima Province.

sen.j: このように記紀では事実の経緯・叙述の趣向が異なっている。
sen.e: Like this, in "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan" the history and description of facts differ.
Like this, in "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan" the history and description of facts differ.
Like this, in "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan" the history and description of facts differ.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』の説の問題点は、飯豊青皇女が執政を始めた時は億計尊・弘計尊の兄弟はもう宮中にいて、この兄弟の代理で一時的に政務を預かったにすぎないばかりか、ちょうど都合よくなぜか1年に満たない執政10ヶ月で死去して顕宗天皇が即位したため清寧天皇と顕宗天皇の間には空位年がないことになっていることである。
sen.e: The problem of the theory of "Nihonshoki" is that Oke no mikoto's brothers had already been in Imperial Palace when Iitoyo no himemiko began her administration and on behalf of the brothers she just temporarily did administration and conveniently after her 10 months' administration, which was short for one year, she passed away and Emperor Kenzo was enthroned and thus there was no blank year between Emperor Seinei and Emperor Kenzo.

The problem of the theory of "Nihonshoki" is that Oke no mikoto's brothers had already been in Imperial Palace when Iitoyo no himemiko began her administration and on behalf of the brothers she just temporarily did administration and conveniently after her 10 months' administration, which was short for one year, she passed away and Emperor Kenzo was enthroned and thus there was no blank year between Emperor Seinei and Emperor Kenzo.

The problem of the theory of "Nihonshoki" is that Oke no mikoto's brothers had already been in Imperial Palace when Iitoyo no himemiko began her administration and on behalf of the brothers she just temporarily did administration and conveniently after her 10 months' administration, which was short for one year, she passed away and Emperor Kenzo was enthroned and thus there was no blank year between Emperor Seinei and Emperor Kenzo.

sen.j: これは『日本書紀』が編年の都合上、飯豊女王の執政期間を切り詰めたのではないかと疑われる。
sen.e: This is suspiciously considered to be because "Nihonshoki" cut her administration period for its convenience of editing the years.
This is suspiciously considered to be because "Nihonshoki" cut her administration period for its convenience of editing the years.
This is suspiciously considered to be because "Nihonshoki" cut her administration period for its convenience of editing the years.

sen.j: 『古事記』の場合、先々の皇位継承がどう考えられていたのかが不明瞭である。
sen.e: In the case of "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), how the previous succession to the Imperial Throne was considered is not clear.
In the case of "Kojiki", how the previous succession to the Imperial Throne was considered is not clear.
sen.cmt: (The Records of Ancient Matters)はすでに出ているため削除しました。
sen.e: In the case of "Kojiki", how the previous succession to the Imperial Throne was considered is not clear.

sen.j: 男子後継者候補がまったくいなかったとすると、飯豊王の執政は問題の一時先送りにしかならず、後世の女性天皇と比べてもまったく類例のないことになる（それゆえ『日本書紀』を正しいとする説もある）。
sen.e: If there was no successor of a son, the administration by Iitoyo no himemiko is a mere postponement of the problem and comparing with later Empress she was totally exceptional (thus, some theory think "Nihonshoki" was correct).

If there was no successor of a son, the administration by Iitoyo no himemiko is a mere postponement of the problem and comparing with later Empress she was totally exceptional (thus, some theory think "Nihonshoki" was correct).

If there was no successor of a son, the administration by Iitoyo no himemiko is a mere postponement of the problem and comparing with later Empress she was totally exceptional (thus, some theory think "Nihonshoki" was correct).

sen.j: 逆に、後世の女帝のあり方から類推すると、男子皇族間の皇位継承争いの予兆があってそれを緩和ないし未然に防ぐ意図があったかとも思われる（少なくともこの時、後の継体天皇が属した応神天皇に連なる息長氏系と、倭彦王が属した仲哀天皇に連なる家系の二つはあり、他にも男系子孫がいた可能性もなくはない）。
sen.e: On the contrary, estimating from the later Empress, as there was a predictor of a succession struggle among male Imperial families, she is thought to have tried to prevent or ease it in advance (at least at that time, there were two family lines such as the Okinaga clan descending from Emperor Ojin whom the later Emperor Keitai belonged to and the family line descending from Emperor Chuai whom Yamato hiko no o belonged to and it is possible for her to have had the other male descendants).

On the contrary, estimating from the later Empress, as there was a predictor of a succession struggle among male Imperial families, she is thought to have tried to prevent or ease it in advance (at least at that time, there were two family lines such as Okinaga clan descending from Emperor Ojin whom the later Emperor Keitai belonged to and the family line descending from Emperor Chuai whom Yamato hiko no o belonged to and it is possible for her to have had the other male descendants).
sen.cmt: the Okinaga clan→Okinaga clanに訂正しました。
sen.e: On the contrary, estimating from the later Empress, as there was a predictor of a succession struggle among male Imperial families, she is thought to have tried to prevent or ease it in advance (at least at that time, there were two family lines such as Okinaga clan descending from Emperor Ojin whom the later Emperor Keitai belonged to and the family line descending from Emperor Chuai whom Yamato hiko no o belonged to and it is possible for her to have had the other male descendants).

sen.j: 執政期間は不明であるがもし長期間に及んだものであれば中継ぎとはいえ本格的に女帝に近い存在だったといえよう。
sen.e: Her administration period is not known, but if it lasted for a long time she is said to have almost been an authentic Empress though a relay successor.
Her administration period is not known, but if it lasted for a long time she is said to have almost been an authentic Empress though a relay successor.
Her administration period is not known, but if it lasted for a long time she is said to have almost been an authentic Empress though a relay successor.

sen.j: また億計尊・弘計尊の兄弟は早くから飯豊王の保護下に匿われており、発見は半ば出来レースだったという一種の折衷案的な説もある（下記の若井敏明の説などもその一種）。
sen.e: And Oke no mikoto brothers were hidden under the guardianship of Iitoyo from early on and some theories say that the discovery was just a setup, which is eclectic (the theory by Toshiaki WAKAI mentioned below is one of them).

And Oke no mikoto brothers were hidden under the guardianship of Iitoyo from early on and some theories say that the discovery was just a setup, which is eclectic (the theory by Toshiaki WAKAI mentioned below is one of them).

sen.j: これに対し、物語の構成・展開に信憑性を認め、発見は本当に偶然だったとする説（角林文雄など）もある。
sen.e: On the other hand, there are some theories that say the discovery was really accidental, admitting the credibility of structure and development of the story (the one by Fumio KAKUBAYASHI).
On the other hand, there are some theories that say the discovery was really accidental, admitting the credibility of structure and development of the story (the one by Fumio KAKUBAYASHI).

sen.j: 出自：履中天皇皇女か皇孫か。
sen.e: Place of origin: Emperor Richu's Princess or Imperial descendant?
Place of origin: Emperor Richu's Princess or Imperial descendant?
Place of origin: Emperor Richu's Princess or Imperial descendant?

sen.j: 『古事記』・『日本書紀』履中紀が父を履中天皇 / 母を葦田宿禰（葛城襲津彦の子。
sen.e: In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters)" and "Nihonshoki" and Richuki, her father was Emperor Richu and her mother was ASHIDA Sukune's (a child of KATSURAGI no Sotsuhiko.
In "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki" and Richuki, her father was Emperor Richu and her mother was ASHIDA Sukune's (a child of KATSURAGI no Sotsuhiko.

sen.e: In "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki" and Richuki, her father was Emperor Richu and her mother was ASHIDA Sukune's (a child of KATSURAGI no Sotsuhiko.

sen.j: 羽田八代宿禰とも）の女・黒媛とするのに対し、『書紀』顕宗紀に引く「譜弟」は父を市辺押磐皇子 / 母を葛城蟻臣の女・媛（はえひめ）とする。
sen.e: or Haneda Yatsushiro Sukune) wife Kurome no Iratsume and on the other hand, in 'Futei' cited in Kenshoki in "Nihonshoki," her father was Prince Ichinobe no Oshihano and her mother was KATSURAGI no Ariomi's wife Haehime.

or Haneda Yatsushiro Sukune) wife Kurome no Iratsume and on the other hand, in 'Futei' cited in Kenshoki in "Nihonshoki," her father was Prince Ichinobe no Oshihano and her mother was KATSURAGI no Ariomi's wife Haehime.

tit.j: 執政者ではなく、託宣の巫女だった？
tit.e: She was not an administrator, but a miko (a shrine maiden) of takusen (oracle)?
She was not an administrator, but a miko (a shrine maiden) of takusen (oracle)?
She was not an administrator, but a miko (a shrine maiden) of takusen (oracle)?

sen.j: 『古事記』の解釈はさらにわかれる。
sen.e: The interpretation in "Kojiki" is further divided.
The interpretation in "Kojiki" is further divided.
The interpretation in "Kojiki" is further divided.

sen.j: 折口信夫の解釈によれば、飯豊皇女は巫女であるか、ないしはそれに近い神秘的な人物であり、執政していたのではなく、清寧天皇崩御後に、巫女として「誰に皇位についてもらうべきか」と神託を仰がれて、その段階ではまだ発見されていなかった億計尊・弘計尊の兄弟の名を託宣したのだという。
sen.e: According to Shinobu ORIGUCHI's interpretation, Iitoyo no himemiko was a miko or a mysterious figure near to it, and she did not administer but was asked for shintaku (oracle) 'who should be on the throne,' after the demise of Emperor Seinei, and she delivered an oracle of the name of Oke no mikoto brothers who had not been found at that stage.

According to Shinobu ORIGUCHI's interpretation, Iitoyo no himemiko was a miko or a mysterious figure near to it, and she did not administer but was asked for shintaku (oracle) 'who should be on the throne,' after the demise of Emperor Seinei, and she delivered an oracle of the name of Oke no mikoto brothers who had not been found at that stage.

According to Shinobu ORIGUCHI's interpretation, Iitoyo no himemiko was a miko or a mysterious figure near to it, and she did not administer but was asked for shintaku (oracle) 'who should be on the throne,' after the demise of Emperor Seinei, and she delivered an oracle of the name of Oke no mikoto brothers who had not been found at that stage.

sen.j: ただし、神功皇后や倭姫命などの例があるように古代の女性皇族で巫女的な資質をもっていた人がいてもまったく不思議ではないが、記紀をみる限り、飯豊女王について巫女的な要素が直接うかがわれるような記述があるわけではなく、あまり巫女的な面を強調しすぎることには慎重であるべきとする説もある。
sen.e: However, it is not strange that there existed people who had a miko-type character in ancient female Imperial families like Empress Jingu or Yamato hime no mikoto and so on, but in "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan" there is no description which suggests that Iitoyo no himemiko had a miko-type character and some theories say that you should be careful to emphasize her miko aspect too much.

However, it is not strange that there existed people who had a miko-type character in ancient female Imperial families like Empress Jingu or Yamato hime no mikoto and so on, but in "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan" there is no description which suggests that Iitoyo no himemiko had a miko-type character and some theories say that you should be careful to emphasize her miko aspect too much.

However, it is not strange that there existed people who had a miko-type character in ancient female Imperial families like Empress Jingu or Yamato hime no mikoto and so on, but in "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan" there is no description which suggests that Iitoyo no himemiko had a miko-type character and some theories say that you should be careful to emphasize her miko aspect too much.

sen.j: →巫女ではなく巫の項、及びシャーマニズムの項を参照のこと
sen.e: => See the section of fu or kannagi (female spiritual medium) or shamanism, not of miko.
=> See the section of fu or kannagi (female spiritual medium) or shamanism, not of miko.

tit.e: There were two Iitoyo no himemikos?
There were two Iitoyo no himemikos?
There were two Iitoyo no himemikos?

sen.j: 飯豊王は二人いたという説がある。
sen.e: Some theories say that there were two Iitoyo no himemikos.
Some theories say that there were two Iitoyo no himemikos.
Some theories say that there were two Iitoyo no himemikos.

sen.j: つまり系譜上での「履中天皇皇女説」と「市辺押磐皇子王女説」はどちらも正しく、履中皇女と履中皇孫は別人で、両者は叔母と姪の関係であったという説。
sen.e: That is, the theory says, genealogically, both 'the theory of Emperor Richu's Princess' and 'the theory of Prince Ichinobe no Oshihano's Princess' are right and Richu Princess was different person from Richu Imperial descendant and both were in the relation of aunt and niece.

That is, the theory says, genealogically, both 'the theory of Emperor Richu's Princess' and 'the theory of Prince Ichinobe no Oshihano's Princess' are right and Richu Princess was different person from Richu Imperial descendant and both were in the relation of aunt and niece.

That is, the theory says, genealogically, both 'the theory of Emperor Richu's Princess' and 'the theory of Prince Ichinobe no Oshihano's Princess' are right and Richu Princess was different person from Richu Imperial descendant and both were in the relation of aunt and niece.

sen.j: 門脇禎二の説と若井敏明の説とがある。
sen.e: There are the theory by Teiji KADOWAKI and the one by Toshiaki WAKAI.
There are the theory by Teiji KADOWAKI and the one by Toshiaki WAKAI.
There are the theory by Teiji KADOWAKI and the one by Toshiaki WAKAI.

sen.j: 両説のちがいは、門脇禎二の説では叔母の方は青海郎女、姪の方は忍海郎女・忍海部女王であり、ともに同じ「飯豊」という別名を与えられている（「青海」がつく方が叔母（皇女）で、「忍海」がつく方が姪（王女））。
sen.e: The difference between them is that the aunt was Aomi no iratsume and the niece was Oshinumi no iratsume, Oshinumibe no himemiko and both of them were given another name (the one with 'Aomi' was the aunt (Imperial princess) and the one with 'Oshinumi' was the niece (princess)), according to the theory of Teiji KADOWAKI.

The difference between them is that the aunt was Aomi no iratsume and the niece was Oshinumi no iratsume, Oshinumibe no himemiko and both of them were given another name (the one with 'Aomi' was the aunt [Imperial princess] and the one with 'Oshinumi' was the niece [princess]), according to the theory of Teiji KADOWAKI.

The difference between them is that the aunt was Aomi no iratsume and the niece was Oshinumi no iratsume, Oshinumibe no himemiko and both of them were given another name (the one with 'Aomi' was the aunt [Imperial princess] and the one with 'Oshinumi' was the niece [princess]), according to the theory of Teiji KADOWAKI.

sen.j: これに対し、若井敏明の説では、叔母（皇女）の方は「青海」「忍海」であり忍海部や飯豊ではなく、姪（王女）の方は「忍海部」または「飯豊青」であり忍海や青海ではない（「忍海」の二字が共有されているが叔母は「部」の字がつかず姪の方は「部」の字がつく）とする。
sen.e: On the other hand, in the theory of Toshiaki WAKAI, the aunt (Imperial princess) was 'Aomi' and 'Oshinumi,' not Oshinumibe and Iitoyo, and the niece (princess) was 'Oshinumibe' and 'Iitoyoao,' not Oshinumi and Aomi (they share the two words 'Oshinumi' (忍海), but the one of aunt has no 'be' (部) while the one of niece has 'be.')

On the other hand, in the theory of Toshiaki WAKAI, the aunt (Imperial princess) was 'Aomi' and 'Oshinumi,' not Oshinumibe and Iitoyo, and the niece (princess) was 'Oshinumibe' and 'Iitoyoao,' not Oshinumi and Aomi (they share the two words 'Oshinumi' [忍海], but the one of aunt has no 'be' [部] while the one of niece has 'be.')

On the other hand, in the theory of Toshiaki WAKAI, the aunt (Imperial princess) was 'Aomi' and 'Oshinumi,' not Oshinumibe and Iitoyo, and the niece (princess) was 'Oshinumibe' and 'Iitoyoao,' not Oshinumi and Aomi (they share the two words 'Oshinumi' [忍海], but the one of aunt has no 'be' [部] while the one of niece has 'be.')

sen.j: このように同じ二人説でも、その二人の名前のちがいをどう考えるかは説が分かれている。
sen.e: Thus, in the same two-persons theory, the interpretations of the difference of the two names differ among them.
Thus, in the same two-persons theory, the interpretations of the difference of the two names differ among them.
Thus, in the same two-persons theory, the interpretations of the difference of the two names differ among them.

sen.j: （叔母が「青海郎女」で姪が「忍海部女王」であることは両者共通。
sen.e: (What is common is that the aunt was 'Aomi no iratsume' and the niece was 'Oshinumibe no himemiko.'
(What is common is that the aunt was 'Aomi no iratsume' and the niece was 'Oshinumibe no himemiko.'
(What is common is that the aunt was 'Aomi no iratsume' and the niece was 'Oshinumibe no himemiko.'

sen.j: 「飯豊」と「忍海」について見解が分かれる）
sen.e: The opinion is divided between 'Iitoyo' and 'Oshinumi.'
The opinion is divided between 'Iitoyo' and 'Oshinumi.'
The opinion is divided between 'Iitoyo' and 'Oshinumi.'

tit.j: 執政者と諮問回答者が別々にいた？（若井敏明の説）
tit.e: The administer was a different person from a inquiry answerer? (the theory by Toshiaki WAKAI)
The administer was a different person from an inquiry answerer? (the theory by Toshiaki WAKAI)
The administer was a different person from an inquiry answerer? (the theory by Toshiaki WAKAI)

sen.j: 上記の若井敏明の説によれば、「叔母の青海皇女は後継をどうすればよいか諮問されて飯豊女王を指名しただけで、青海皇女は執政はしていない。
sen.e: According to the above theory of Toshiaki WAKAI, 'the aunt Aomi no himemiko was asked questions regarding the successor, she just appointed Iitoyo no himemiko and Aomi no himemiko did not administer.
According to the above theory of Toshiaki WAKAI, 'the aunt Aomi no himemiko was asked questions regarding the successor, she just appointed Iitoyo no himemiko and Aomi no himemiko did not administer.
According to the above theory of Toshiaki WAKAI, 'the aunt Aomi no himemiko was asked questions regarding the successor, she just appointed Iitoyo no himemiko and Aomi no himemiko did not administer.

sen.j: 一方、姪の飯豊女王は執政はしたが諮問に預かったのではなく、青海皇女の指名に基づいて飯豊女王が執政したのである」という。
sen.e: On the other hand, the niece Iitoyo no himemiko administered, but was not asked questions and she administered based on the appointment by Aomi no himemiko.'
On the other hand, the niece Iitoyo no himemiko administered, but was not asked questions and she administered based on the appointment by Aomi no himemiko.'
On the other hand, the niece Iitoyo no himemiko administered, but was not asked questions and she administered based on the appointment by Aomi no himemiko.'

sen.j: また青海郎女は巫女というわけではなくて、単に皇位継承問題の対策を諮問されて、飯豊王の名を回答しただけであり、神託というようなものとはみなしていない。
sen.e: And Aomi no himemiko was not a miko and she was simply asked questions regarding succession to the Imperial Throne, and answered the name of Iitoyo no himemiko and did not give an oracle.
And Aomi no himemiko was not a miko and she was simply asked questions regarding succession to the Imperial Throne, and answered the name of Iitoyo no himemiko and did not give an oracle.
And Aomi no himemiko was not a miko and she was simply asked questions regarding succession to the Imperial Throne, and answered the name of Iitoyo no himemiko and did not give an oracle.

sen.j: また忍海部（青海郎女の部民）と忍海宮はもともと青海郎女のもので、「市辺押歯王が殺された時に飯豊王女は叔母の宮に身を寄せたのであり、男子と関係をもったという伝承も姪の飯豊王女の方」とする。
sen.e: And Oshinumibe (the folks of Aomi no himemiko) and Oshinumi were originally the one of Aomi no himemiko and 'when Ichibe no oshiha no miko was killed, Iitoyo no himemiko escaped under her aunt miya and the tradition that she had a sexual intercourse with a man was for the niece Iitoyo no himemiko.'

And Oshinumibe (the folks of Aomi no himemiko) and Oshinumi were originally the one of Aomi no himemiko and 'when Ichibe no oshiha no miko was killed, Iitoyo no himemiko escaped under her aunt miya and the tradition that she had a sexual intercourse with a man was for the niece Iitoyo no himemiko.'

And Oshinumibe (the folks of Aomi no himemiko) and Oshinumi were originally the one of Aomi no himemiko and 'when Ichibe no oshiha no miko was killed, Iitoyo no himemiko escaped under her aunt miya and the tradition that she had a sexual intercourse with a man was for the niece Iitoyo no himemiko.'

tit.j: 関係する地名、神社など
tit.e: Related place names, shrines and so on.
Related place names, shrines and so on.
Related place names, shrines and so on.

tit.cmt: ピリオド削除しました。

sen.j: 現在、福島県にある飯豊山の「飯豊」は「いいで」と読んでいる。
sen.e: At present, '飯豊' of Mt. Iidesan in Fukushima Prefecture is read as 'iide.'
At present, '飯豊' of Mt. Iidesan in Fukushima Prefecture is read as 'iide.'
At present, '飯豊' of Mt. Iidesan in Fukushima Prefecture is read as 'iide.'

sen.j: 代表的な地名起源説としては、「いひとよ」は古語でフクロウであり、おそらくはフクロウの住む山という意味で「いひとよ山」といったのが後世に訛って「いいで山」になったというものである。
sen.e: As a typical theory of the origin of place name, 'ihitoyo' meant an owl in ancient words and probably in the sense of the mountain where owls live, 'ihitoyo yama' changed to 'iide yama' in later years.

As a typical theory of the origin of place name, 'ihitoyo' meant an owl in ancient words and probably in the sense of the mountain where owls live, 'ihitoyo yama' changed to 'iide yama' in later years.

As a typical theory of the origin of place name, 'ihitoyo' meant an owl in ancient words and probably in the sense of the mountain where owls live, 'ihitoyo yama' changed to 'iide yama' in later years.

sen.j: また、古代に「豊」を「て」、「で」、「てみ」、「でみ」、「とみ」、「どみ」等と読んだ可能性もある（この他にも、この山の名の由来についてはいろいろな面白い説があるが飯豊女王と関係ない話なので省略）。
sen.e: And there is a possibility that '豊' was read as 'te,' 'de,' 'temi,' 'demi,' 'tomi,' 'domi,' and so on in ancient times (in addition to this, concerning the origin of name of this mountain, there is an interesting theory, but it is not relevant with Iitoyo no himemiko and thus omitted.

And there is a possibility that '豊' was read as 'te,' 'de,' 'temi,' 'demi,' 'tomi,' 'domi,' and so on in ancient times (in addition to this, concerning the origin of name of this mountain, there are many interesting theories, but they are not relevant to Iitoyo no himemiko and thus omitted.
sen.cmt: theoryを複数形にしたことによる変更、およびwith→toの変更しました。
sen.e: And there is a possibility that '豊' was read as 'te,' 'de,' 'temi,' 'demi,' 'tomi,' 'domi,' and so on in ancient times (in addition to this, concerning the origin of name of this mountain, there are many interesting theories, but they are not relevant to Iitoyo no himemiko and thus omitted.

sen.cmt: 原文・訳文のクォーテーション調整

sen.j: 「古老曰へらく、昔、巻向珠城宮（まきむきのたまきのみや）に御宇（あめのしたしろしめしし）天皇の二十七年戌午年の秋、飢えて人民多く亡せき。」
sen.e: Old man said that formerly in autumn in the year of the horse of Emperor Gyou (Ame no shita shiroshimeshishi) twenty-two year in Makimuki no tamaki no miya, many people died from hunger.
Old man said that formerly in autumn in the year of the horse of Emperor Gyou (Ame no shita shiroshimeshishi) twenty-seven year in Makimuki no tamaki no miya, many people died from hunger.
Old man said that formerly in autumn in the year of the horse of Emperor Gyou (Ame no shita shiroshimeshishi) twenty-seven year in Makimuki no tamaki no miya, many people died from hunger.'
sen.cmt: 原文・訳文のクォーテーション調整

sen.j: 「故、宇惠々山と云ひき。」
sen.e: Thus, it was called Ue no yama (mountain of hunger).
Thus, it was called Ue no yama (mountain of hunger).
Thus, it was called Ue no yama (mountain of hunger).'
sen.cmt: 原文・訳文のクォーテーション調整

sen.j: 「後に名を改め豊田と云ひ、飯豊と云ふ。」
sen.e: Later it was changed to houden (rich rice field) and Iitoyo.'
Later it was changed its name to houden (rich rice field) and Iitoyo.'
sen.cmt: its nameを付けました。本文下の項目に’」’があったので、この行の本文最後に付けました。
sen.e: Later it was changed its name to houden (rich rice field) and Iitoyo.'
sen.cmt: 原文・訳文のクォーテーション調整

sen.j: この中に出てくる飯豊青尊とはもちろん本項の飯豊女王。
sen.e: Iitoyo ao no mikoto who appears in this is the Iitoyo Princess for sure.
Iitoyo ao no mikoto who appears in this is the Iitoyo Princess for sure.
Iitoyo ao no mikoto who appears in this is the Iitoyo Princess for sure.

sen.j: 豊岡姫命とは記紀にいうトヨウケヒメのこと、巻向珠城宮御宇天皇は垂仁天皇のことである。
sen.e: Toyooka-hime referred to Toyoukehime in "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan" and Emperor Gyou in Makimuki no tamaki no miya was Emperor Suinin.
Toyooka-hime referred to Toyoukehime in "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan" and Emperor Gyou in Makimuki no tamaki no miya was Emperor Suinin.
Toyooka-hime referred to Toyoukehime in "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan" and Emperor Gyou in Makimuki no tamaki no miya was Emperor Suinin.

sen.j: なお、「飯豊」という地名はこの飯豊山の他にも、東北地方の各地にある。
sen.e: And as for the place name of 'Iitoyo,' there are the ones across Tohoku region in addition to the Mt. Iidesan.
And as for the place name of 'Iitoyo,' there are the ones across Tohoku region in addition to the Mt. Iidesan.
And as for the place name of 'Iitoyo,' there are the ones across Tohoku region in addition to the Mt. Iidesan.

sen.j: 詳しくは「飯豊」を参照のこと。
sen.e: See the details in 'Iitoyo.'
See the details in 'Iitoyo.'
See the details in 'Iitoyo.'

sen.j: 福島県白河市に「飯豊比売神社」があり、御祭神が飯豊比売神である。
sen.e: Iitoyo Hime-jinja Shrine' is in Shirakawa city, Fukushima Prefecture and the enshrined deity is Hime no kami.
Iitoyo Hime-jinja Shrine' is in Shirakawa city, Fukushima Prefecture and the enshrined deity is Hime no kami.
Iitoyo Hime-jinja Shrine' is in Shirakawa city, Fukushima Prefecture and the enshrined deity is Hime no kami.

sen.j: 福井県大飯郡高浜町の「青海神社」には、飯豊女王が禊をしたという池があり、伝承にまつわる神事が伝わる。
sen.e: In 'Aomi-jinja Shrine' in Takahama-cho, Oi-gun, Fukui Prefecture, there is a pond where Iitoyo Princess purified herself and Shinto rituals related with tradition have been handed down.
In 'Aomi-jinja Shrine' in Takahama-cho, Oi-gun, Fukui Prefecture, there is a pond where Iitoyo Princess purified herself, and Shinto rituals related to tradition have been handed down.
sen.cmt: コンマとwith→toの変更しました。
sen.e: In 'Aomi-jinja Shrine' in Takahama-cho, Oi-gun, Fukui Prefecture, there is a pond where Iitoyo Princess purified herself, and Shinto rituals related to tradition have been handed down.

sen.j: 奈良県葛城市の「角刺神社」は飯豊女王の「角刺宮」跡と伝えられ境内に飯豊王女が鏡として使ったという池がある。
sen.e: Tsunosashi shrine' in Katsuragi City, Nara Prefecture is said to have been remains of 'Tsunosashi palace' of Iitoyo Princess and in the shrine there is a pond which she used as a mirror.
Tsunosashi Shrine' in Katsuragi City, Nara Prefecture is said to have been remains of 'Tsunosashi palace' of Iitoyo Princess and in the shrine there is a pond which she used as a mirror.
Tsunosashi Shrine' in Katsuragi City, Nara Prefecture is said to have been remains of 'Tsunosashi palace' of Iitoyo Princess and in the shrine there is a pond which she used as a mirror.

sen.j: 上記の福島県の飯豊山には「飯豊山神社」がある。
sen.e: In Mt. Iidesan in Fukushima Prefecture, as above mentioned, there is 'Mt. Iidesan shrine.'
In Mt. Iidesan in Fukushima Prefecture, as above mentioned, there is 'Mt. Iidesan Shrine.'
In Mt. Iidesan in Fukushima Prefecture, as above mentioned, there is 'Mt. Iidesan Shrine.'

sen.j: 宮城県加美郡加美町の「飯豊神社」は巨石を御神体とする。
sen.e: In 'Iitoyo shrine' in Kami-cho, Kami-gun, Miyagi Prefecture, the big stone is regarded as goshintai (divine object).
In 'Iitoyo Shrine' in Kami-cho, Kami-gun, Miyagi Prefecture, the big stone is regarded as goshintai (divine object).
In 'Iitoyo Shrine' in Kami-cho, Kami-gun, Miyagi Prefecture, the big stone is regarded as goshintai (divine object).

sen.j: 福島県田村郡小野町の「飯豊神社」は秋祭の11月3日に獅子舞が奉納される。
sen.e: In 'Iitoyo shrine' in Ono-cho, Tamura-gun, Fukushima Prefecture, shishimai is dedicated on November 3 of autumn festival.
In 'Iitoyo Shrine' in Ono-cho, Tamura-gun, Fukushima Prefecture, shishimai (a ritual dance by a performer wearing a lion's mask) is dedicated on November 3 of autumn festival.
sen.cmt: 獅子舞の定訳を加え、shrine→Shrineにしました。
sen.e: In 'Iitoyo Shrine' in Ono-cho, Tamura-gun, Fukushima Prefecture, shishimai (a ritual dance by a performer wearing a lion's mask) is dedicated on November 3 of autumn festival.
